content: - Christopher Columbus sights Guyana.
- Dutch establish trading posts upriver.
Much of southern Guyana is covered by Amazonian rainforest
- Dutch West India Company establishes a foothold in Guyana, including armed bases, and imports slaves from Africa to work on the sugar plantations.
- Guyana changes hands several times between the Dutch, French and British.
- Britain occupies Guyana during the Napoleonic Wars.
- Major non-violent slave rebellion crushed in Demerara.
- Guyana officially declared a British colony.
- Slavery abolished; many slaves leave plantations to set up their own freeholdings and are replaced by indentured workers mainly from India.
- Gold is discovered in Guyana and is followed by an economic boom.
- Venezuela lays claim to a large portion of Guyana west of the Essequibo river.
- International arbitration tribunal rules in favour of Guyana (then called British Guiana) in the territorial dispute with Venezuela.

- Britain suspends Guyana's constitution, sends in troops and installs an interim administration after democratic elections for parliament produces a result not to its liking - a victory for the left-wing Indo-Guyanese Progressive People's Party (PPP).

- Britain restores Guyanese constitution; PPP splits along racial lines, with Cheddi Jagan leading a mostly Indian party and Forbes Burnham leading a party of African descendants, the People's National Congress (PNC).
- Guyana granted full autonomy, with Britain retaining control over internal and defence matters; Jagan of the PPP becomes prime minister.
- Venezuela revives its territorial claims on Guyana; Cheddi Jagan introduces austerity programme, sparking off violent riots and a general strike; British troops sent in to restore order.
- Racial violence between people of African origins and Indian supporters of Jagan.
- Guyana becomes independent with Forbes Burnham as prime minister.
- Guyana becomes a republic within the British Commonwealth with Raymond Arthur Chung as titular president.
- Nine hundred members of a religious sect commit mass suicide at Jonestown, a community established by sect leader Jim Jones.
- Guyana gets a new constitution and Burnham becomes the country's first executive president.
- Desmond Hoyte (PNC) becomes president following the death of Burnham; economy begins to deteriorate.
- PPP wins first completely free parliamentary elections since independence; Cheddi Jagan becomes president.
- Jagan dies and is replaced by his wife, Janet, after elections.
- Government declares state of emergency in Georgetown in response to violent riots amid allegations of discrimination by PPP against Afro-Guyanese.
Cheddi Jagan served as prime minister before independence - 1961-4 - and later as president - 1992-7
- Bharrat Jagdeo becomes president after Janet Jagan resigned for health reasons.
- Long-running dispute with Suriname over the offshore border comes to a head when Surinam gunboats evict an oil exploration rig from the area. Guyana had approved the exploration.

July - TV presenter Mark Benschop charged with treason. Court says he encouraged protest in which presidential complex was stormed by demonstrators, who were complaining of discrimination against Afro-Guyanese.
April - US embassy employee is kidnapped and released after a ransom is paid. The abduction is part of a wave of violent crime; the murder rate in 2002 quadrupled to more than 160.
May - Home Affairs Minister Ronald Gajraj steps down to allow an inquiry into allegations that he is linked to a death squad accused of executing hundreds of suspected criminals.
June - UN sets up tribunal to try to resolve long-running maritime border dispute between Guyana and neighbouring Suriname.
President Jagdeo campaigned for action on climate change and in 2007 called for slavery reparations
December - Jury at trial of TV presenter Mark Benschop, charged with treason in 2002, fails to deliver unanimous verdict, necessitating re-trial.
January - Government declares the capital a disaster zone as severe flooding follows days of continuous rain. More than 30 people are killed. UN estimates loss to the economy to be $500m.
April - Ronald Gajraj reappointed as interior minister after inquiry clears him of direct involvement in killings of known and suspected criminals. He resigns in May.
April - Agriculture Minister Satyadeow Sawh is shot dead. The murder is part of a string of gun crimes. The ruling party says the killing is intended to incite pre-election violence.
August - President Bharrat Jagdeo wins another five-year term in general elections.
June - Former Guyanese MP Abdul Kadir is arrested in Trinidad on suspicion of involvement in a plot of blow up New York's JFK airport.
September - A UN tribunal rules in the Guyana-Suriname dispute over maritime territory, giving both a share of a potentially oil-rich offshore basin.
July - President Bharrat Jagdeo accuses the EU of using its economic might to 'bully' developing nations into accepting its terms in negotiations with 16 Caribbean countries over a trade agreement.
Artistic traditions testify to many Guyanans' African or Indian origins
October - President Jagdeo signs trade agreement with EU.
October - Parliament abolishes mandatory death penalty for murderers, unless they have killed members of security forces.
November - Donald Ramotar is elected as president. Ruling People's Progressive Party loses majority at parliamentary elections, but remains largest party.
July - Three die as police clash with demonstrators protesting against electricity price hikes.
November - President Ramotar suspends opposition-dominated parliament just before it debates no-confidence motion in his government. Opposition accuses him of undermining democracy.

May - Former senior army officer David Granger of the Afro-Guyanese Partnership for National Unity and Alliance for Change wins presidential election by slim margin, ending 23 years of rule by Indian-dominated People's Progressive Party.
ExxonMobil announces "significant" oil discovery off Guyana in waters claimed by Venezuela, which repeats its claim. Guyana seeks UN mediation.
December - Coalition government loses parliamentary majority, raising possiblity of early elections.
